August 18, 1945
Gertie Darling
I wrote you a hurried line yesterday about general affairs and
this morning I want to give you a few thoughts that I have on the future. It
appears that I can get out of the navy out here if I wish to. This would immediately
make me a civilian and then you could cone out without any trouble. Providing of
course that there is transportation. Truman said that there were more ships in the
Pacific than they knew what to do with so that tranportation may not be as difficult
as it first seems. The other thing would be for me to get out of the Navy back on
the mainland.
The advantages of getting out here would be that you could come out
and see what you think of the place. We could decorate the shop and give Gerry a hand
as she is absolutely swa[m]ped right now, and then in the latter part of November we could
go back to [T]he states shoot at Medway and go onto Florida for the bad weather. In this 
way we could have  a pretty good idea by Spring what we think of the various places
and would be better off in knowledge when it cones to comparing advantages and disadvantg
If I decide to get out of the Navy back on the mainland I will have to awaitx
my orders to the mainland and transportation there. The latter will cause
delay because the traffic is all one way back to the Mainaland. Of course there are
so many things that will come up within the next two or three days that [perhaps] my decison
will be made for me.
I an enclosing a copy of a letter from Knoth relative to timbering
the plantation. I an still in favxxing of doing this rather than renting it ,
I think becaux se we will always be timbering as a steady source of inca
me to support the place while if we rent it we will not be able to use
it ourselves. It would be fun to shoot it this winter due to the fac[t]
that is has[sh]ot been shot for three years and should provide very good sp
sport.
This machine isgiving me the Jitters. I think it has the ["]war over bug["]
and does nothing it is supposed to. It is not my own but one in my new
office and I am at its mercy. Have played tennis with Morris and
some of the men at the club several times since my return andplayed very
badly. We have been beaten each time, and buble belley says that is
because I went to school and tried to use my brain instead of my body.
[End Page 1]
My first kmpression of this place was that the Ala Wai lo_oked like a
rather shabb_y southern town. That thepalms were stunted and wind blown
and that the people were second rate. However after a [f]ew deys my eyes have
become accoustosed to it all and I again think it is attractive and that
the clim[T]e is marvellous. The water is so warm that you can play
purpoise in it for ever and never be cold. The sun is so strong that
in one day on the beach I became as black as an indian. However Waikiki
beech is second rate. The water is not clear, the beach is not attractive
and the people lying around maybe alright in war time but not in peace.
Many of the people that I knew like Mr and Mr Bradshaw are going to back to
the mainland because they say that they do not think there will be anyone
here after the war. However they of course are not taking into account
the peop_le who have always lived here.
Henry DeGore the manager of the Outrigger has left for Frisco because
he says that there are no schools that are worth a dam for his children and
that he would not bring them up here with all the orientals. There are all
these things to consider and I think that the next few months will be in
a constant state of flux and that the islands will not really adjust thems -
elves for perhaps a yeer. Big plans are on foot for the erection of a
hotel on Mauix by the Matson line. They are going to have x tennis
courts riding and golf. Fifty rooms very attractive right on the sea
with palm[s]and all sorts of tropical sorroundings. The reason for this
is that they say they realizie that Honlulu has lost the charm of its
hawaiian atmosphere and that some other place must take it up if tourists
are to come. I think they are right because Waikiki is not the sort of
place that you can say how lovely , just like the south seas.
This afxt[e]rrnoon I an going to see the man in charge of tranpo
rtation for civilians an_d also the man who has control of Navy wives
comming out. Will write and let you know what is happening. Bet you are
one jump ahead of a fit wondering what we are going to do and when we are
goingto do it. Just remember that I love you the most in the world and 
that it is almost all over and if you will just have a little more
patience everything will come out alright and these years will be just
a dream to be forgotten or talked about xxx because they were so extra
ordinary.
Good bye darling.
Sidney
Sidney
[End Page 2]
[enclosed]
ROBERT F. KNOTH [and] CO.
Foresters - Appraisers - Surveyors
39 Broad Street
Charleston 3, S. C.
August 11, 1945
Mr. Sidney J. Legendre,
P.O.Box 166,
Navy No. 128,
Fleet Post Office, San Francisco, Cal.
Dear Mr. Legendre:
I have, via Mr. Lowndes, your letter to him of the 3rd.
First I must say that I am glad to heard you and Mrs. Legendre are both alive,
and I presume kicking, and possibly back in the states.
Monday, unless it is V-J day I am going to run over Medway to refresh my
mind on the timber and if not Monday the first day possible this week. Upon
reviewing the cutting plan we worked up for Medway I not that it would
be possible to operate this tract on a three year basis taking off about
1,000,000' - 1,500,000' B.M.-Part of this cut being made up of pole-piling
timber, the remainder from sawtimber.-I know exactly how you want the operation
handled. The above volume is conservative and totals about 65-70[percent] of the
growth made in the years since 1942 or in other words the past 3 years, thus
the original forest capital has not only remained intact, but will, even after
removing 1,500,000', be increased by 770,000' to approximately 13,500,000'.
Upon looking the tract over I will report to you my recommendations. It
will be about 8 weeks before we can do any actual timber marking, however as
I have to run down to Alabama for the Ewing Estate on a timber cruise
which will take that long. [The Ewing's incidently make Carpets or something
in New York and perhaps Mrs. Legendre knows them] In any even I do not 
recommend cutting before fall as this cuts down pine beetle damage to the
remaining trees, the beetle being very active in summer timber operations and
frequently killing trees that have been inavoidably scarred during logging
operations.
Our service charges are 10[percent] of the gross stumpage returns as I informed you
once on the Plantation. This fee is not exorbitant and in fact is very reasonable
taking into consideration that we select and mark the timber to be felled,
tally its volume,draw up the timber sale contracts, enforce the contract 
requirements,[by weekly field inspections, obtain responsible purchasers and
most important obtain the prevailing market price or better, see that the
[End Page 3]
[enclosed]
2. Contd.
money is paid and that you have honest and efficient service. Attention
to road damage of course would be covered in the timber sale inspections
and supervision as the operation progresses.
I might call to your attention that the collecting and burning o tops is
a little on the impractical side and unless you have some special reason
for this practice I would recommend its abandonment for the practice we have
found best suited to the lowcountry, i.e. lopping the remaining tops so that
no more than two feet of the top lies above the ground surface. This eliminates
serious bug damage, makes it easy to shoot over the tops, satisfys the aesthetic
views of the owner and does not interfere with cattle grazing. Such lopped
tops being in close contact with the ground completely rot in a matter of
a two to three year period. An area logged in this fashion looks not unlike
an unlogged area from 200 feet or so.
If the operator desires to place a ground mill on the tract we will choose
the point for him and make certain that the sawdust pile is so handles that
it can be readily burnt and the area cleaned up so that no signs will be left
after three or so years. The site to be in a back area where it will become
no eyesore while in operation.
As stated above I fully appreciate the way you want this timber cut, and from
personal angle I want to do the job from the best possible forestry standpoint
just to prove to Mr. Richardson that he is a DF in cutting all his timber at
one time against my recommendations, and also for the future business a good
forestry job will bring in.
We are also going to handle similar operations on Mr. H. B. Hollins 'Braodmarsh'
Plantation and Mrs. D. R. Noyes, 'Dawn Plantation' this winter.
Sincerely yours,
--
Robert F. Knoth
[End Page 4]
